New research has found that large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT consistently advise women to ask for lower salaries than men, even when both have identical qualifications.

The study¬†was co-authored by Ivan Yamshchikov, a professor of AI and robotics at the Technical University of W√ºrzburg-Schweinfurt (THWS) in Germany. Yamshchikov, who is also the founder of Pleias, a French‚ÄìGerman startup building ethically trained language models for regulated industries, worked with his team to test five popular LLMs, including ChatGPT.

They prompted each model with user profiles that differed only by gender but included the same education, experience, and job role. Then they asked the models to suggest a target salary for an upcoming negotiation.

In one example, ChatGPT‚Äôs o3 model was prompted to give advice to a female job applicant. The model suggested requesting a salary of $280,000.

This is far from the first time AI has been caught reflecting and reinforcing systemic bias. In 2018, Amazon scrapped an internal hiring tool after discovering that it systematically downgraded female candidates. Last year, a clinical machine learning model used to diagnose women‚Äôs health conditions was shown to underdiagnose women and Black patients, because it was trained on skewed datasets dominated by white men.¬†

The researchers behind the THWS study argue that technical fixes alone won‚Äôt solve the problem. What‚Äôs needed, they say, are clear ethical standards, independent review processes, and greater transparency in how these models are developed and deployed.

As generative AI becomes a go-to source for everything from mental health advice to career planning, the stakes are only growing. If unchecked, the illusion of objectivity could become one of AI‚Äôs most dangerous traits.
